comments.commentBody:
I don't believe a single thing that Dean Baquet says about the 2016 coverage. The Times has been after the Clintons for 25 years. Isn't it about time that you owned up to it? Remember Whitewater? I'm still waiting to see the apology for that.

Not one of your readers buys into the hand-wringing act about wanting to publish the dossier but just couldn't. "While his findings were difficult to confirm, Times reporting bore out that he was respected in his craft. And of his material that was checkable, no significant red flags emerged." Maybe you don't think that corrupt ties to a foreign power are newsworthy, yet the chance that a foreign power might hack someones personal email is. That's crazy. Or it would be if you didn't have a strong bias about what to report.

Meanwhile, the ludicrous Comey allegations commanded the front page for days. Let us review them, shall we? To be new news, the email downloaded from a server had to be different from what was on the server. That is, of course, impossible-- but the Times found it credible. Email neither to nor from Hillary Clinton had to somehow implicate her in some terrible wrongdoing that her own emails did not. Not impossible, but vanishingly unlikely. And yet the Times found it credible.

You need to admit that the Hillary stories were only publishable because your purpose was to harm her candidacy, and that the Trump allegations weren't for the same reason. You got her, take a victory lap.
Cancel my subscription!
I canceled mine yesterday due to the utter failure of the NYT in their watchdog capacity re Trump.  The operator said "you're not the only one who feels this way."

During the summer and autumn of 2016, daily, and in vain, I searched reliable news sources like The New York Times for more about the Trump-Putin connection. It seemed there had to be more, and I couldn't understand why no one was pursuing the story.

I think it is hard to avoid the conclusion that not publishing the entire dossier  was inexcusable, rather than irresponsible.   How is it ethical that the FBI was investigating, official Washington was chattering, but the press decided to keep it secret from voters?  Journalistic "ethics" are clearly overdue for a major re-examination.

Sadly ironic to see this column followed on my digital news by the Times plea, Got a confidential tip?  Imagine the slush pile of tips that go unreported.  A truly disheartening portrait, and today we inaugurate the consequences.

The Times did essentially the same thing to Al Gore in '99-'00. If Al Gore had gotten elected there would have been no Iraq invasion/occupation and we'd be among the countries leading the way in fighting climate change and clean energy deployment. Now we'll go backward for another 4 years on CO2 mitigation. The 8 years of Bush admin climate change denial may have determined the fate of humanity.

When push comes to shove, you guys have done your utmost to put your finger on the scale to help elect 2 of the worst presidents in US history.

What the heck are you thinking?

The most frustrating part of this piece is the continued equivocating. I wonder if today's editors would have published the Pentagon Papers.  Likely not.  Some kind of journalist ideal put before a moral imperative.  The editors should feel complicit in the results of this election.

...this while it was quite obvious that Hillary was being witch hunted.
You can ask Kevin McCarthy....he'll explain.

I've been thinking about cancelling my subscription ever since election night. How could NYT have been so wrong? After reading this it convinces me that cancelling my NYT subscription is what I need to do. It seems to me complacent executive editorial liberal thinking also caused a hugely important story to be suppressed. And I'm not convinced the gusto necessary to keep up with Trump bullying and bait and switch tactics is there. Whatever happened to hard-hitting investigative journalism? When I see it again, I will come back. Then and only then.

A repeat of the Times support for the invasion of Iraq - and intelligence claims about WMD that justified it - followed by similar support for the war on Libya and Syria. Is this a semi-apology for the constant anti-Russian tone from the Times columnists and reporters. It the time now for friendship and cooperation between countries with different systems of government. Peace before hostility  and the wars that follow from it.

Finally some acknowledgment from the times of the inadequacy of the reporting on this issue. I have written to the editors several times about this as I'm sure have many, many other NY Times subscribers.  But really, this falls into the category of too little, too late. The Times should be ashamed, absolutely ashamed, of its coverage of the trump, Russia connection.

Where is the editorial denouncing Trump's inaugural address, lie by lie, outrage by outrage? Someday we may learn why cowardice prevailed on the Newspaper of Record at a crucial moment in American history. Until then, let's see some gutsy journalism starting now. Maybe the Times should hire some fresh talent to repair the damage its irresolution has caused.

The problem is timing, and impact on the election. Comey came out with an entirely bogus claim of a re-opened investigation of Hillary's emails, ten days before the election. There was no evidence to support that claim, but the NYT reported it, and everyone agrees that the reporting of tjis bogus claim hurt Hillary significantly. By holding back on reporting more substantial claims of Trump's nefarious ties to Russia, the NYT portrayed Hillary as dirty, and Trump as clean, while the opposite is true. The NYT and its media cohorts helped elect a dangerous charlatan, and did serious damage to a noble, worthy presidential candidate. Shame on you, I hope you can't sleep.

I'm really shocked by this.  Dean Baquet protests angrily that they didn't "sit on stuff."  But, it appears, they did.  Investigations are reported all the time, even when it turns out that there was nothing there.  That's basically been the story of Hillary Clinton's life.  And, we're treating this walking scandal of a man with kid gloves -- breathlessly reporting that the FBI's outrageous last-minute Hillary email business that had nothing to it, and covering up that the FBI is investigating Trump about more serious matters?  How can the Times justify this double standard?  The article is polite about it, but it seems outrageous to me.

Thank you, Liz Spayd, for a strong and courageous piece of ombudsmanship for Times' readers. It cannot have been easy for you to write your piece knowing The Times' management would be looking at every word.

I too as a Clinton supporter can lament the fact that Baquet didn't publish these Russian connection stories before the election but as a reader I can also understand if the Russian story's sources had proven false what we'd be saying about Baquet today.

What I want to thank The New York Times for is paying you to do such work as displayed in this column. Regardless of what I think of Baquet's decision, I, for sure, can support his newspaper's ombudsmanship.
And why is this Public Editor mea culpa located in very small print at the bottom of the page?

Elijah Cummings today on CNN:
"You’ve got to understand that we members of Congress have a lot of information that the public does not have. And I can tell you over the last week or two, the classified briefings that I have been to, and if the public knew what members of Congress know..."
http://www.dailykos.com/story/2017/01/20/1622716/-One-Rep-s-Ominous-Warn...
Before this is "over" you guys will look worse than you do today.
So the FBI not only withheld information on Trump's investigation but also discouraged the media from reporting on it? Did the FBI also discourage the media from reporting on Hillary's investigation?
I almost just renewed ---
This is why I find myself abandoning the Times for the Washington Post more and more these days.

The reporting was like a repeat of that before the Iraq war. The Times supported the invasion and the fiction about WMD. After an apology it went on to support "regime change" in Libya and Syria. The results are horrendous. The present article may - hopefully -  be the preface for a new apology in relation to Russia. The world need friendly relations between the major powers and not assumptions of intellectual and moral superiority.

This is the part that jumped out at me: "In each instance, it was the actions of government officials that triggered newsroom decisions — not additional reporting or insight that journalists gained."

Why do you have reporters if they aren't able to find out anything? Especially the newspaper in Trump's home base. He's a real estate businessman who has worked in the area for years, and no one has information about him? Unbelievable!

One of the ongoing problems with NYT has been clickbait-oriented titles (written by editors!) that are not supported by the stories they lead into. There wasn't a failure of reporting--there was a failure of leadership at the Times. The editors failed their readers.

Why do the mea culpas always seem to be too little, too late with the Times?  The Times aggressively joined in every Republican PR initiative of the past 20 years, from hounding the Clintons over Travelgate, Filegate, Whitewater, etc. during the '90s, to hazing Al Gore over wearing earth tones and sighing during a debate, to buying into every Bush administration lie about Saddam's supposed WMDs and support for terrorism, to now making a phony issue over Hillary Clinton's emails the central issue of the campaign while downplaying much more serious ethical issues with Donald Trump, Russia and his family "charity."  The Republicans have gotten away with murder on your watch.  Can it really be an accident that it keeps happening over and over, and the apologies always come too late to matter?

You bastards. You have failed us mightily.

Get off your lazy ------ and get busy going after the regime quite literally while you still have the chance to do so. Lives literally depend on it. Stop counting your ad revenue, worrying about your stock price and your compensation packages, and start focusing intensely on the stark reality that is aimed at us all. NOW. DO IT. Don't come back to this same space with another sorry apologia when it's too late, sadly it may already be.
